title: Environmental Sustainability Measurement and Management | Singapore Institute of Technology

meta.description: Specialised micro-credential for strong technical and theoretical foundation in environmental sustainability measurement, management and practical application through project-based learning. Earn a Specialist Certificate and stack it towards a degree in Electrical and Electronic Engineering or Infrastructure and Systems Engineering.

text_lines: Browse Professional Exams and Preparatory Courses
Browse Professional Exams and Preparatory Courses

Specialised micro-credential for strong technical and theoretical foundation in environmental sustainability measurement, management and practical application through project-based learning. Earn a Specialist Certificate and stack it towards a degree in Electrical and Electronic Engineering or Infrastructure and Systems Engineering.
Specialist Certificate in Environmental Sustainability Measurement and Management
As the world and Singapore increasingly prioritise sustainable development, the demand for environmental sustainability knowledge and skillsets within the workforce is rapidly growing.
This micro-credential aims to equip learners with competencies to measure and manage environmental sustainability as solutions are implemented.

Learners will explore the foundational sciences of environmental sustainability, recognising the pivotal role of the natural environment in sustaining the economic system. This understanding sets the stage for comprehending the necessity and rationale behind employing specific metrics. General frameworks and processes like carbon accounting and life cycle assessment, as well as sustainability reporting frameworks, standards, processes, and techniques will also be introduced.

Additionally, learners will explore the tools and techniques for driving sustainable development, including sustainability business models, green financing, sustainability strategies (including climate change mitigation and adaptation), and sustainable development policy.

Learners will then address project problems, which include defining and measuring sustainability states, and developing solutions to advance sustainability. Learners will pitch these solutions to demonstrate their understanding of applied sustainability measurement and management.
This micro-credential is an unrestricted elective within the CSM Pathways in

Learners who are seeking to enhance their expertise in environmental sustainability across diverse industry sectors, including sustainability officers, building facility managers, engineers, policymakers, service managers, and product managers.

This micro-credential provides learners with both theoretical knowledge and practical skills essential for addressing environmental sustainability challenges, from understanding environmental sciences to implementing sustainable strategies.

During the course, you will have access to a team of qualified success coaches who can work with you on learning strategies or to develop a personalised learning plan. Through the success coaches, you can gain access to a wide range of resources and support services, and be empowered with the necessary tools to navigate your learning journey successfully.
Assoc Professor/Head of Sustainability (Education and Research), Office of the Deputy President (Academic) & Provost, Singapore Institute of Technology
Assoc Professor/Head of Sustainability (Education and Research), Office of the Deputy President (Academic) & Provost, Singapore Institute of Technology

Associate Professor Ethan Chong specialises in sustainable development, engineering design, and artificial intelligence. As the Head of Sustainability (Education and Research) in the Office of the Provost, he develops SIT’s overall strategy for educational programmes in sustainability while extending and synergizing applied research activities related to sustainability. Dr. Chong envisions an industry driven by cutting-edge technologies and a continuous learning paradigm founded upon the requirements of the future economy. In SIT, he also supports the industry in developing solutions and manpower through training, consultation, and R&D.
Associate Professor, Engineering, Singapore Institute of Technology
Associate Professor, Engineering, Singapore Institute of Technology

Dr Jeffrey Kwik is currently an Associate Professor at the Singapore Institute of Technology involved in their sustainability program. He was a senior researcher at the National University of Singapore studying various aspects of community ecology and biology in Singapore’s aquatic habitats; a lecturer at the University of Queensland co-ordinating their Australian marine biology programs; and a lecturer at Temasek Polytechnic teaching aquaculture, fish husbandry, health, and disease management.

Dr Kwik is a fish biologist and ecologist with more than 30 years of experience studying fishes in both freshwater and marine habitats, and across tropical to temperate ecosystems in countries including Singapore, Indonesia, Fiji, and Australia. His specific areas of expertise include trophic and community ecology, growth and development, invasive biology, reproductive biology, and the sensory biology of fishes. He has more than 30 publications on fish research in journals such as the Journal of Morphology, Ecological Engineering, Biological Invasions, Hydrobiologia, and Journal of Applied Ichthyology; and is on the journal editorial boards of the Raffles Bulletin of Zoology, Philippine Journal of Systematic Biology and Aquatic Ecosystems Health and Management.

Since 2005, he also has been involved in several consultancies looking at the aquatic diversity in Singapore’s waters including five PUB-commissioned involving applied research projects such as studying the freshwater fish communities and characterizing the food webs in the reservoirs and waterways of Singapore; researching the environmental impacts of floating solar panels on the aquatic and avian communities within and along the perimeters of reservoirs; and most recently, investigating the applications of nature-based solutions (i.e. biomanipulation techniques) for improving water quality and controlling nuisance issues (i.e., midges) in Singapore’s reservoirs.
Assistant Professor, Engineering, Singapore Institute of Technology
Assistant Professor, Engineering, Singapore Institute of Technology

Dr. Hu Chengcheng has over 10 years of experience in sustainability research and practice, working with diverse stakeholders—including government agencies and industry sectors such as manufacturing, technology, finance, food, and oil & gas—to translate strategy into action. As a subject matter expert in Life Cycle Assessment (LCA), she helps clients understand and reduce the carbon footprints of their products and services. Her expertise spans a wide range of domains, including product sustainability, carbon finance, circular economy, sustainable supply chains, carbon accounting and reporting, assurance, and regulatory research and strategy development related to sustainability. Chengcheng holds a PhD in Environmental Engineering from Nanyang Technological University (NTU), supported by the prestigious NRF Clean Energy Scholarship. She has also earned global sustainability certifications from leading institutions such as Cambridge and DTU, and holds the Advanced Certificate in Learning and Performance (ACLP) from WSQ.
A Specialist Certificate in Environmental Sustainability will be issued to learners who:
Attend at least 75% of the course
Undertake and pass all credit bearing assessments
The learner will undertake a combination of remote proctored assessments, written assessments, and group project.
The full fee for this course is S$9,868.86.
Funded under SkillsFuture Mid-Career Enhanced Subsidy (MCES)
will be collected before course commencement.
All fees above include GST. GST applies to individuals and Singapore-registered companies.

Should you decide to convert to the degree pathway, you will be subject to SIT’s tuition fees and may qualify for the Ministry of Education (MOE) tuition grant, based on eligibility criteria set by MOE. Please note that the SkillsFuture subsidy will no longer be applicable once you convert to the degree pathway.
